reviewDescription: First of all, I purchased the 256gb model, and it only has 232gb of capacity.  With the first one I received, I tried transferring some files to it, and it kept giving me an error like the drive was disconnecting and reconnecting.  So Amazon sent me another one and the same thing happened.  HD-Tune showed 98% damaged sectors.  I figured I would just try formatting the drives before I send them back, so I did.  After formatting the drives, both work as they're supposed to.  Also, this drive gets extremely hot.  It makes me wonder if the heat is somehow responsible for the damaged sectors.  Both times I formatted I let them cool off to room temp first.

reviewTitle: Try these as soon as you get them
reviewDescription: Had these for 4 days past the 30 day return window.  Went to copy 28 gigs of photos to share with relatives only to have 1 of the 3 thumb drives get really hot and disconnect from the pc after 4 minutes of copying files.  It does it each time it is I've tried to copy files.  I've tried copying smaller batches of files and the same thing happens: it overheats and disconnects.  I guess it will eventually take the files if you allow the thumb drive to cool off between transfer sessions, which I would recommend be no more than 4 minutes of copying at a time with a 5 minute cool down before your next attempt.So........... Highly recommend you copy 10 gigs of test files to these when you first get them to see if you received a dud as well.Overall, I have always been very happy with SanDisk equipment.  This is the first BAD experience I've had with them.

reviewTitle: This product is a bit fragile
reviewDescription: If you use it a lot and or put it in your car with music like I do it starts to bend when it's inside of the slot and unfortunately for the price it's not worth it then. Have been through several of these and will not buy this brand anymore.

reviewTitle: Flash Drive Already Open and Used
reviewDescription: I paid for a new flash drive; the one sent was opened, taped back together, and used. The only reason I'm giving 2 stars instead of one is because so far, it's working. Really unprofessional, lazy, and low quality control. Pretty disappointing.

reviewTitle: Does not work for what i need it to do
reviewDescription: These flash drives do not work for what i need it to do - it uploads the music from my PC (plenty of storage space) but it does not play the music on my truck sound system - but it will play it on all my PC's in my home but not when I plug it into the USB port on my sound system in the truck. I put the same music the same way on a flash drive I had (not as much storage space) and that works in the truck but these flash drives shows up on my truck sound system as no device detected. Since the new vehicles of today don't have CD players in them they put USB ports for playing music.

reviewTitle: Out of 2 Drives, one failed immediately with write-protected error.
reviewDescription: Ordered the 2-pack Sandisk Ultra USB3.0 64gb drives.  After copying about 10 files onto the first drive, started getting the error "The disk is write-protected".  This has made the drive unusable, cannot add or delete files (I can read the files though).  I am hesitant to return the drive as my data is on it, and I am unable to remove it now (can't delete, format or re-partition).After some googling, I see this is a common problem (at least with SanDisk USB drives), once this message occurs, basically the USB drive is toast...So far the second drive seems to be ok...Update: Contacted SanDisk, they sent a replacement after I provided some basic information on the FlashDrive that failed.  Back in business...

reviewTitle: I learned the hard way not to keep data on these things for a long time !!!
reviewDescription: Whats never advertised is the fact your data is less secure as they go up in capacity .I left some video on one of these for a couple years .I can no longer copy any of the files from the drive . I can view the video but constant errors anytime I try and move a file .I don't trust these things and practice is showing me that I should not !HDD's and optical may be outdated but I would like to see what happens to a PC with one of these "wonder drive" SSD's in it ? ALL MY ARCHIVE DATA IS STORED OPTICALLY .I still have music CD's that I bought in 1987 .......they still play perfectly .
Very slow for what I need it
I just use it once for install linux system and then it is broken.
I purchased 1 2 pack of the 128 GB 06.25.2024.Both display 114 gb as others have statedI just would like the truth and honesty in the advertising of what  I am paying for.

reviewTitle: A good, albeit slightly wonky, flash drive
reviewDescription: 512 GB is a ton of storage, so this flash drive will get a lot of use from me. I primarily am using this to store copies of personal files and it works great for that, the copying speed is good. My only real problem with this is that the lever you push to push the USB port up and down feels rather wonky to me, it takes some resistance to do. It can also be a bit of a tight fit in some ports; it fit perfectly fine in my computer, but when I put it in my PS5 it felt like I was jamming it in there (it does still fit and work as intended though). Worth noting that this flash drive comes with some files already on it, that being instructions on how to install some sort of SanDisk software, but you can just delete those and still use it with no problems.

reviewTitle: Reliable and Fast USB 3.0 Flash Drives
reviewDescription: I bought the SanDisk 32GB 3-Pack Ultra USB 3.0 Flash Drives, which have been fantastic for my needs. I use them primarily for installing Windows operating systems, and they easily transfer installers, drivers, utility, and BIOS files. The 32GB capacity is just right for these tasks.They’re small enough to carry around without any hassle, and the USB 3.0 speed makes the process much faster. I've used them on multiple PCs and never had any compatibility issues. These drives are reliable and have become an essential part of my toolkit.If you're looking for dependable and speedy flash drives for system installs and important file transfers, these SanDisk drives are perfect. I highly recommend them!

reviewTitle: Quality flash drive at a decent price
reviewDescription: I use thumb drives for my car's music playlists. I don't use anywhere near the 32GB capacity ... usually limit a playlist to 5GB ... but the drives load the music quickly and they work in the environment of the car ... which can be a bit harsh ... hot and cold extremes. The containers they come in are convenient for storing when not used in the car (I only have one it the car at a time). Helps keep them organized.

reviewTitle: flawless Fedora40/Plasma6.1 install on old Dell 7710
reviewDescription: Making the move to Linux, first step dual boot with Win10 on old Dell 7710 8-core Xeon laptop (still a strong machine but getting squonky about current versions of things). Several other "USB 3.0" USB sticks hung up at different points of the installation process. One USB failed permanently. This Sandisk SDCZ48-128G-GAM46 worked flawlessly and was as fast as advertised, much faster than the older sticks, always nice. Highest++ recommendation.

reviewTitle: Decent for ISOs, too slow for heavy use
reviewDescription: These are great and priced right for long term cold storage of small amounts of data, or for ISOs.  These two USBs, combined with a multi-ISO bootable software like Ventoy, are all you need to store many operating systems, rescue disks, backup programs, and other boot media efficiently.  These are excellent for the price.These are absolutely the wrong product for system backup/restore, large data backup, and media production.  Honestly, even the best flash drives (e.g. 2TB Kingston) will heat up like a nuclear reactor under such loads.  Your best bet is portable SSD (preferrably USB 3.2 gen2x2 for 20GBps, or even USB 3.2 gen2x1 at 10GBps) which will operate very fast at a reasonable temperature and still be small enough to easily carry in your shirt pocket.

I like the retractable USB connector.  I like the fact that this is USB3.0 so it is fast.  I am video professional and I need to be able to transfer video files fast.  This has 512gig so it has enough space for a lot of files. You can not beat the quality and consistency of the SanDisk products.

Excessive heat was a big concern when purchasing these flash drives.  However, after copying almost 120 Gig of non-stop data to one flash drive, I can report that the drive did not get very hot.  If compared to water temperature, I would judge the flask drive temp to be in the luke-warm area.However, write speed was running at only 15-20 MB/s, so the date transfer rate was not as fast as I had anticipated but that could have been a function of my laptop computer.  Nevertheless, I consider excessive heat to be a bigger potential problem/concern than date transfer speed, so I'm very happy with these flash drives.

The drives I was sent have the problems written in other reviews. Gets hot quickly after writing to the drive, and they get nowhere near their max speed of 130mb/s. reviewTitle: Password software is not included and the download process does not work
reviewDescription: The Drive is supposed to have pasword protection but the password softwre is not included in the flash drive so that you have to download it.  When I click on "install sandisk software.exe," it takes me to a Western Digital page from which I installed the security software, which I then click.  A window opens that says "attach a supported WD drive."  It does not work and nowhere does it recognize the SanDisk external drive.I finally Googled how to install password software to SanDisk Ulta 3.0 and followed the following instructions:Connect the SanDisk USB flash from to the computer.Download SecureAccess. ...Copy SanDiskSecureAccessV3_win.exe to the USB flash drive. ...Double-click on SanDiskSecureAccessV3_win.exe.Click Next.Check the box to accept the License Agreement and Privacy Statement.

reviewTitle: works good but would be nice if it had a led to tell when working
reviewDescription: no let to tell if it is loading or downloading

reviewTitle: Maybe fast writes on a 16GB drive, if you get lucky
reviewDescription: For a cheap drive, this is probably one of the best you can find. Although it does not have blazing speed, you don't expect that at this price point. But you do get a solid drive, with positive locking retractable plug.The write speeds don't make you feel like you are waiting forever to put your data on the disk, and reading back is also very fast.An even better deal is the 3-pack of the 32GB size...it gives you 6 times the total storage for about 3 times the cost.EDIT: The 3-pack of the 32GB drive is cheap, and you get what you pay for. Read speeds at high queue depth are still good, but read at lower queue depth and write speeds are about 50-60% of the 16GB version.EDIT: And, the next 16GB drive I bought had the same terrible write speed as the 32GB drives, and the read speed has dropped a bit from the first 16GB drive. These write speeds are below USB 2.0 speed, so tell me why SanDisk claims this is a "USB 3.0" drive? I should have paid more attention to their claim of "5x faster than a standard USB 2.0 drive (4MB/sec)". USB 2.0 can easily handle 30MB/sec.

Bei vielen oder größeren Dateien, z.B. einem Film, werden gemittelt ca. 25 MB/s erreicht, manchmal nicht einmal 15 MB/s. Der Stick wird schnell heiß, vermutlich hat das Einfluss darauf. Purchased and received from Amazon the package of two SanDisk Ultra USB 3.0 128GB flash drives. Simply could not copy the contents of an old flash drive --- one still working fine --- onto one of the new ones. Almost solely MS Office files, PDF files, and the like; nothing fancy.  Tried the other drive; no luck.  Tried to read the endless verbiage on the package; the font is so small that it is impossible to read even with a magnifying glass. Would it have killed Western Digital (the producer) to have included an instruction sheet actually readable?  Do the drives have to be formatted?  No way to know.  Is there software that has to be downloaded?  No way to know.  Tried to find a customer service phone number on the web; there isn't one.  Instead, there is a chat function (which I rather dislike) at the end of which the assistant sent a form to fill out to get a phone call from a technician.  Supposedly $1, "fully refundable."  Filled out the form, submitted it, and then Western Digital tried to charge my credit card $63.  (The two drives in total cost about $24.)  Is this supposed to be Western Digital's idea of how their customers should be treated?  I will never buy a SanDisk/Western Digital product again.  In contrast, Amazon's customer service rep for returns was great.  BZ

reviewTitle: don;t buy can't get replacement lids from company buy instead stanley flip straw tumbler
reviewDescription: I purchased a  Sandisk USB 3.0 256gb as I needed a storage drive for study labs. What a waste of money but more importantly, a waste of my time. Both of these USB's are "write protected" which basically makes them useless. (These do not have an outside physical switch to turn on/off). You cannot store anything or even open the drive until it is "formatted" but you can't format it because it's "write protected." I shouldn't have to pay Sandisk extra money to remove the write protection from a product I purchased from them, so I refused to go that route. I viewed countless online help forums for this specific issue and none of the methods listed helped at all. (cmd, Windows Registry, 3rd party apps, etc.) This is beyond ridiculous and Sandisk should be slapped with a class action lawsuit for this practice. I found several other people online with the exact same issue and nothing helping to remove the write protection. This has caused me countless hours that I could have dedicated to studying outside of working hours. no insruction wer includedeven theirwebsite reqyired fiddling wit a verifivaion code.i woul avoidbuyin from this company.

reviewTitle: Slower than cheap USB 2.0 flash drive!
reviewDescription: Unpacked and immediately tested with H2testw for data integrity and speed. H2testw writes 1Gb files to the drive until full. It took 51:55 minutes to write the drive to full capacity! Write speed was 9.42 MB/s! Read speed was 68.2 MB/s. Unpacked the second drive and tested with the same results. I was shocked. SanDisk scamming buyers? I decided to test USB 2.0 flash drive to compare them. I bought 16GB 5-pack last year and they currently sell for $13.99 for a pack of 5. The brand is DEEKOO, Chinese manufacturer. Same app, wrote to full capacity. The write speed was 10.1 MB/s! The nominal 64GB drive has a true capacity of 61524148224 bytes, or 61.52GB, or 57.31GiB, or 120164352 sectors of 512 bytes each. This is before any partition table or filesystem is created.I created a FAT32 filesystem on the drive, and sequentially wrote 60 files of 1.00GB each, containing encrypted zeros (effectively, random data). The total time was 4744.81 seconds (including the sync command), for an average rate of 12.6MB/s. Non-sequential writes would be slower, but 12.6MB/s should be considered the maximum possible write speed of the drive.On reading back the files, the first 52 files were error free. After that, the drive failed, and seemed to reboot its controller repeatedly. I noted that the drive was too hot to touch, even through its plastic case. I disconnected and reconnected the drive, and the rest of the files verified correctly. The overall read speed was 142MB/s when there weren't any errors.All these tests were done with the drive sitting in open air, at 72 degrees F ambient temperature. Reading a huge amount of data off the drive should be done carefully, in shifts, to avoid overheating it. Idling and write accesses don't seem to make the drive overheat, but the metal connector always feels uncomfortably warm after unplugging it, even if you hardly do any operations.Note that I did all these tests on a USB 3.x superspeed port. If you use a USB 2.0 or USB high speed port, your speed will likely be limited to 30MB/s.I removed 1 star for lying about the capacity (3.9% is missing from the advertised size), and another star for lying about the write speed (it claims to be 10 times faster than a 4MB/s USB drive, which is 40MB/s, but it actually can't write faster than 12.6MB/s). I still gave 3 stars, because it is faster than other USB flash drives I've tested of similar capacity.

It takes 30 minutes+ for each of the 3 drives to format 32GB with command line utility.Going by what I read on the Sandisk forum, they are aware of the problem but will not fix it. Third hand information but if it's true that is troubling considering Sandisk is supposed to be a good brand.I looked at the huge selection of thumb drives on Amazon and was tempted to get a brand I've never heard of but opted to go with a 'name brand' because I was worried about getting an unreliable drive. reviewTitle: Good for basic use, but QLC flash like performance will be an issue for large files.
reviewDescription: I purchased the 3 pack of the 32GB drives knowing that it would be slow to write, but the marketing will mislead many users. The write speeds are slower than many low cost USB 2.0 flash drives from 7-10 years ago, and that is likely due to the use of QLC NAND which has a major write speed penalty. Read speeds being high is common since additional flash levels only really carry an ECC burden, where if the controller is fast enough, then the speed penalty is minimal.Since the drive seems to also have a tiny amount of faster storage (likely to also handle other controller management data), it will also create misleading results from smaller benchmarks that may only use a fast region of NAND. With this in mind, I did a linear read and linear write from 0 to 100 %.Read performance: Reads are quite good with an average of 159.7MB/s that is largely sustained throughout the entire length of the drive.Write performance: Writes are significantly slower, with a 0-100% average of 17.9MB, but that average is influenced by the initial higher speeds in the 30-36MB/s range. Without that initial faster section, the speeds very frequently bounce around 15-17MB/s. Furthermore, this represents a best case scenario as it is a 100% linear write done as raw writes, ignoring any partitioning or file system. Anything that increases the IO workload, will result in lower write performance.Overall, if you need a flash drive for basic use (documents, images, audio, etc., then this Is a great budget option, but if you need something for larger transfers, such as multiple GB videos, linux live USBs, and other mixed uses that can result in wither large transfers, then don’t go with anything lower than the Sandisk Extreme flash drives, as pretty much all of their lower end units have gotten slower over the years in terms of write speeds, while read speeds have steadily increased.

I have around a dozen Old Generation SD Ultra 3.0 Flash Drives and have never had a problem, unlike some reviewers. But I started buying the New Generation 32GB and even 2 64GB drives, and they all suffer from the same "bugging out" problem. Meaning that when I initially plug them in, the antivirus chimes and asks if I want to scan the drive. After that the Old Gen can sit in the port for hours without issues. However these New Gen will bug out within 1-15 min, repeatedly, meaning there's the chime that's made when the drive is removed, and immediately the antivirus asks again if I want to scan. Any file transfer is stopped, any video being watched crashes, etc. So there must be some bad connection in these New Gen. It would be easy to blame a bad lot if they were all the same size or came from the same seller, but when the problem affects both multiple 32GB and 2 64GB drives bought from different sellers, I can only blame some change in the product by SanDisk. The only physical difference between Old and New is that the blue plastic slab seen at the bottom, the connection point, is much thicker in the Old Gen, with that in the New Gen barely perceptible. No clue if that's part of the problem, simply pointing out the only physical difference I can see. And it's not my USB ports since other makers, like Samsung and PNY, work just fine on the computer, for hours and hours. So I won't be bothering with SD Ultra 3.0 New Gen anymore. Buyers beware.

reviewTitle: The 256 GB Ultra USB 3.0 Flash Drive falls far short of advertise speeds
reviewDescription: I ordered two SanDisk 256 GB USB 3.0 Flash Drives.  I tested one of them to see if the advertised speeds were credible.  On the factory shipping card, SanDisk asserts that the read speeds are "Up to 10x faster than USB 2.0 drives" and "up 130 MB/s READ".I used HDTune Pro to perform benchmarks on two significantly different computers.  For the tests, both computers were quiescent, both used primary USB 3.2 ports (i.e., not hubbed), and both used the same brand new SanDisk drive (fresh from the shipping card).The actual measured speeds were consistent for both tests:  the USB 2.0 speeds averaged about 20 MB/s, and the USB 3.2 tests averaged about 40 MB/s.  So the numbers fell far short of SanDisk's claims - not anywhere near "Up to 10x faster than USB 2.0 drives" and "up 130 MB/s READ".These were the simplest tests possible;  I decided that write tests were irrelevant.I'm very disappointed, and I'm going to return both of these drives.

reviewTitle: Plenty of storage for the budget user, but has major limitations as well.
reviewDescription: I recently purchased several of the 512GB version of the SanDisk Ultra USB to back up my work and other e-files. I am pleased at the size at which these USBs are available. The actual size available for storage was roughly 460GB out of the 512GB.As many previous reviews mentioned, the USB tip (metal part) gets really hot upon plugging in. Therefore, it is definitely not something I want to plug into my laptop for prolonged work sessions fearing heat damage. Also, I had varying experiences when writing files to this USB. Writing numerous small sized files significantly drops the transfer speed, sometimes, to as low as 100Kb/s.Overall, I would recommend the USB if you just need many cheap, and highly portable devices for double or triple back up of your less frequently used files. The USB provides the most storage per cost basis compared to many alternatives. But, keep in mind of the over-heating and the slow transfer issues.

I have sometimes saved the situation by pulling the stick out when I get the erroneous message, but once the program succeeded in deleting the source folder on my hard drive.If you don't use their security software, this is a fine product. I don't know in what country the software was written, but it was somewhere with little quality control. The encryption algorithm seems to work, but the practical side can ruin things.

This is a genuine SanDisk USB thumb drive.  I only buy SanDisk from reputable sellers because there are too many counterfeit and fake drives out there.  The fake drives promise huge storage sizes for a fraction of the price, and trick your PC or laptop into displaying a fake capacity, but they only store a small amount of data and just keep pretending to write.  When it comes time to read your data, it can only retrieve the small amount and the rest of your data is gone.  SO ONLY BUY ORIGINAL SANDISK from known sellers!

reviewTitle: Lots of space, but pre-formatted with FAT32
reviewDescription: I bought these to store large file for video editing when it's not practical to transfer them over the network.  The first thing I found out is that they are pre-formatted with FAT32 which has a maximum file size of 4GB.  I reformatted them as exFAT and the problem is solved.Performance is decent for the price.  I measured speeds using USB 3.2 Gen 1 (aka USB 3.0).  Sustained read speed is about 135MB/s.  Burst write speed is about 66MB/s and it maintains that speed for about 1GB before it drops down to 35MB/s.  Most of the files I transfer are 3GB to 5GB in size, so it was a few months before I noticed that write speeds drops down again to 22MB/s after somewhere between 5GB and 6GB of sustained writes.  The speed remains at 22MB/s until at least 17GB which is the largest file I've tried.I also had the opportunity to try this flash drive on a USB 2.0 port.  Sustained read speed is about 38MB/s which is close to the limit of USB2.0.  Burst write speed is about 22MB/s for about the first 1GB, then the sustained speed drops to about 17MB/s.  I expected this to be around 35MB/s since the device can transfer data on USB2.0 at speeds of at least 38MB/s and it can write to it's Flash at speeds of at least 35MB/s.Something else I noticed is that while plugged into a USB2 port, the drive temperature doesn't increase, even when reading or writing for several minutes.  However, when plugged into USB3 port for a few seconds, even when the drive is not being accessed at all, the drive gets fairly warm.  It's not hot enough to burn your skin but it makes me think that leaving the drive plugged into to a USB3 port for extended periods of time (something I normally do) will shorten the life of the drive.

reviewTitle: SanDisk Ultra 256GB: Pathetically Slow Data Transfer Rates
reviewDescription: This device claims speeds up to 130 MB/s. I realize that's marketing hype but average write speeds were 25 MB/s. This is only slightly faster than the ten year old SanDisk Cruzer 64GB (20MB/s). This performance is ok for drive size of 32GB but not for 256 GB unless you are only adding a few files at a time and mostly reading. The drive slows down as it fills too. Capacity value is good. Performance value is poor.A better SanDisk, with increased cost, is the Extreme PRO 256GB. It still doesn't approach the advertised 380 MB/s write speeds. But it averaged 140MB/s on NTFS.  Still no where close to the Samsung T5 2TB which does match write of 380 MB/s. But it also costs 5x more.Tested the Ultra with 72K files ranging is size from 3 GB to < 1KB. Mean size was <10MB.  Best write performance was sizes <100MB approaching 65MB/s . Read time on small files approached 85 MB/s. Surprisingly, files systems exFat and NTFS had similar performance with a slight edge to NTFS.

reviewTitle: Blatant lying about the storage size
reviewDescription: I have purchased the "512 GB" version. I am quite familiar with the usual practice of the storage industry of using decimal Gigabytes to advertise the capacity. The drive I have received has 494206451712 bytes. This is the raw capacity of unformatted and unpartitioned drive as reported by Linux kernel. Obviously, it will be less after formatting. Obviously, it is much less in "true" Gigabytes defined as 1024*1024*1024 bytes (460 GB).I suppose most users will be convinced by the argument that formatted drive has less capacity, as they might have a limited capability to access the size of the raw device. Others will be convinced by the argument of different units for MB and GB. How would they answer to my complaint? Maybe they would say that Linux is not supported? Extremely unlikely, as devices like that use a general protocol not tied to any particular OS.

SanDisk defines 1GB as 1,000,000,00 bytes.

reviewTitle: Not 512 GB. Not even 500 GB. Is 494 GB unformatted.
reviewDescription: Yes, I understand the difference between GB (gigabytes) and GiB (gibibytes) and the difference between raw unformatted capacity and formatted capacity.This flash drive, for me, shows a raw unformatted capacity of 494,206,451,712 bytes or 494.2 GB. Since 512 GB should be 512,000,000,000 bytes, 3.5% of the promised capacity is missing.I'm still giving it 4/5 stars, though, because it works great, doesn't run hot, was inexpensive, and lives up to its promised speed rating (although I have seen throttling when doing sustained writes in a speed test, but that's to be expected). And while a loss of 3.5% is annoying, isn't enough for me to get angry and return it. Sometimes bad blocks are locked out at the factory, and perhaps this disk had an unusual number of them. That being said, it should never have passed quality control, in my opinion.In comparison, I have a 12 TB Western Digital Elements disk that shows an unformatted capacity of 12,000,105,070,592 bytes (0.00088% more than promised), a 128 GB SanDisk Cruzer Glide that shows an unformatted capacity of 128,043,712,512 bytes (0.034% more than promised), and a 64 GB SanDisk Cruzer Fit that shows an unformatted capacity of 63,065,554,944 bytes (1.46% less than promised).Operating system: MacOS 11 Big Sur.

reviewTitle: Very very slow to save files
reviewDescription: I liked the idea of having this much storage in a flash drive and I was glad that I could encrypt the files.  However, this flash drive is very, very slow when it comes to saving files.  I assume that this is due to the encryption process but it takes up to 4 minutes when I copy files onto it before it is ready to use again.  These were not large files (all less than 2 mb each).  I get worried when I see the "Not Responding" message going on for so long.Also, copying and pasting files to this flash drive is very clumsy.  The copy and paste and cut and paste icons don't seem to work.  I have to drag files onto the flash drive.I will go back to Verbatim even though the largest size I can find with them is 256 GB.  It also had encryption and did not take nearly the amount of time that this one does.Unfortunately I have already thrown away the package and so I won't be able to return this.
I could not unprotected it without buying bloatware.  To solve the problem use DISKPART. LIST VOLUME, SELECT VOLUME, FORMAT.

reviewTitle: Dispositivo da 512 GB, velocità in scrittura del tutto inadeguata.
reviewDescription: Pagata 86,90€. Quando tolta dalla confezione la PenDrive, arrivata rapidamente come consuetudine Amazon, si presenta interamente in plastica di buona qualità, almeno così sembra. Anche il meccanismo di apertura e chiusura appare ben fatto ed è facile usarlo con una mano sola. Quando aperto risulta fermato in modo tale da non aver problemi nell’inserimento del dispositivo in una presa USB. Non manca un led dalla luce poco invadente che ne segnala il funzionamento. La PenDrive arriva formattata dal produttore con FAT32 ed è presente un programma di crittografia e le relative istruzioni. Sulla parte frontale della confezione viene indicata, in modo ben visibile, la velocità di lettura che il costruttore dichiara fino a 130 MB/s, quanto riportato sul retro, con caratteri veramente molto piccoli, permette di calcolare, sempre secondo il costruttore, la velocità di scrittura che arriverebbe a 10 volte la velocità standard usb 2.0 di 4MB/s, cioè fino a 40 MB/s.Purtroppo le effettive caratteristiche della parte elettronica sono assolutamente inadeguate: la velocità di scrittura di un file di grandi dimensioni (2,8 GB) supera di poco i 16MB/s ovvero circa il 41% di quanto dichiarato, mentre in lettura risulta essere inferiore, anche se di poco, ai 100 MB/s. La prova è stata eseguita più volte su presa USB 3.0 di un computer dotato di SSD con la PenDrive vuota. Sullo stesso computer, sulla stessa presa e con lo stesso file, una PenDrive Patriot Supersonic, di analoga capacità e prezzo, superava gli 80 GB/s in scrittura e i 250 GB/s in lettura. Data la capienza del dispositivo riempirlo, quando vuoto, con file di grandi dimensioni (lo scenario più favorevole) richiederebbe circa 9 ore, posto che riempiendosi le prestazioni non degradino. Non oso immaginare quanti giorni o settimane ci possano volere se i file sono di dimensioni più contenute.Per quanto mi riguarda è bocciata. Ho effettuato il reso.Kuhn Rath

reviewTitle: Well theres lots of storage. Just not fast.
reviewDescription: It was on sale when i bought it. Needed a large capacity usb drive and the supposed fast write speed convinced me to buy it.  It does have great read speeds, but if your writing to the usb drive and your file is bigger than 1 gig this is no better than usb ver 2.0. The first gig of your file transfer will be 60/ mbs per sec, then it quickly drops off to 20 / mbs after that.Dont ask me to explain but after about 50 write erase write new data cycles it seem to be getting a faster. I have no reason for why that should happen.

reviewTitle: One major issue with this design
reviewDescription: As far as digital operation goes these have been fantastic.  Problem is the wide stick design.  These will not fit side by side in most USB hubs or computers.
Good storage, super fast, a little pricy...don't like the shape or the push to expose the USB for insertion.

reviewTitle: Great USB for daily use, size could be better.
reviewDescription: I recently bought the SanDisk 64GB 2-Pack Ultra USB 3.0 Flash Drives, and I'm quite satisfied with their performance. The speed is impressive—file transfers are quick and efficient, which is exactly what I need for backing up large files and moving data between devices. The USB 3.0 technology definitely makes a noticeable difference compared to older models.However, I did find the size of these flash drives to be a bit bulkier than necessary. While they still fit into USB ports without issue, their slightly larger size can be cumbersome when using adjacent ports or packing them into a tight space. Despite this, the overall quality and speed of the SanDisk Ultra USB 3.0 Flash Drives make them a reliable choice for anyone needing dependable storage solutions.
Good product - note plastic is cheap the hole for my lanyard broke relatively quickly on this
Functional and works well.
I works ok but did not write as fast as I thought it should
Missing like 54gb but other than that its a really good hardrive.

The product is as advertised and came in nice packaging. The drive performs as promised. I chose this drive because it had a lot of good reviews. The company ensures my data is safe and has the space needed to save my files and documents.
The bundle was at a pretty good discount when I bought it, I haven’t got an issue, good product
Yep they work. The price at the time I bought them was convenient.  I recommend them
Received and using. Nothing to compare these with. They were just as shown.

I have reordered these USB3 sticks more than once because they are so dependable.  Out of perhaps 20 Sandisk sticks, only one has ever failed, and that was one of the older USB2 32 GB stick that had the LED activity light.The ONLY thing I don't like is that Sandisk apparently has stopped providing the internal LED that visibly shows disk activity.  If, for instance, Windows Defender is scanning your usbstick to delete Potentially Unwanted Programs (their opinion!)  that you really want to keep, the LED will remind you to Exclude the usbstick from scanning.  I gave it only 4 stars as a message to Sandisk.Does having an LED activity light cause premature failure??? Inquiring minds want to know ...Well, this USB3 Ultra [without LED] is a good buy. I will still purchase more as needed.

I've now had 3 of the SanDisk Ultra USB 3.0 Flash Drives become corrupted and unusable to the extent that a computer will not even recognize them.  That's really disappointing.  At the same time I have a bunch of these floating around the house, office, workshop and car.  Overall they seem to be fairly good and have a good read / write speed.  It's just that every once in a while one with just die.  They're still better than some of the cheap USB sticks I've had, or used, over the years.  Isn't just an annoyance when one dies, and it never happens at a good time.

reviewTitle: Sustained random write speed is ~8.3 MB/s; read is ~100 MB/s
reviewDescription: It might make for a good backup medium if you run your backups in the background so you don't get distracted by the speed. I used up 253 GB of this drive with a backup and at least verified that it's not a false-capacity scam like most of the cheaper drives on various major websites. It took 8 hours and 37 minutes to complete the backup, hence the random write speed estimate in this review's headline, but it's vastly slower at writing small files (Windows reported <1 MB/sec) and faster for large ones (Windows reported >60 MB/sec). I ran my backup and supplementary tests by copying files to and from my insanely fast M.2 SSD (ADATA XPG SX8100, benchmarked around 1 GB/sec write and 1.8 GB/sec read).Unless maybe you're reading this 5 years after I wrote it, you may as well just get an average 1 TB portable spinning disk drive for any short-term storage/between-locations transfers, but the relative longevity of flash memory (as long as you don't write to them often) makes this a decent option for slow backups. This drive would also be fine for write-once, read-many-times needs, especially in cases that your write speed is throttled anyway (e.g. if you're downloading straight to this USB drive from a <500 Mbit/s network).

I needed one of these so i can back up the Sims 4 just in case my computer breaks or something. I didn't try copying the game yet (it's like 16 gb because of all my mods lol) but I did test it with a bunch of random pictures and it seems to work fast enough for me. (20 pictures only took like 5 seconds)Will probably take long to move 16gb but that's to be expected.Only complaint is after testing and removing it (only used for a few minutes) the metal USB part was very hot, hotter than other usbs I've used.But I think it'll be fine if I'm just using it to store some files.I ordered the 64 gb and the actual usable storage on it was about 57gb. That's understandable though. So if you need a certain amount of gb, always buy a larger storage amount just in case.Anyway, if you need a USB that's affordable and decent, this is for you. If you want something more high quality, find something more expensive.

I use SanDisk's thumb drive and it's frustrating that they always have less storage than they claim to have: 32GB thumb drive has 29.3, a 256GB thumb drive has only 233 available, etc.Unfortunately this one is no different and the storage discrepancy far worse. 512GB on the package, but only 460GB on the device itself.I know some people will try to claim that this is due to some esoteric (and trivial) difference with how GB's are calculated but that doesn't wash.Everybody knows that when people say "GB" they're talking about how much storage will be available when they put it into their laptop or desktop and every company knows how to do that.If SanDisk gave me the item and I claimed to have paid them $45 for it, but they found out afterwards that I only gave them $41, nobody would offer excuses for me if I claimed that it's due to some obscure difference in how money is calculated for amazon, Sandisk and myself -nobody would buy that.I've never had problem with SanDisk products but let's all be honest , this is false labeling and it needs to stop.
The drive wouldn’t mount when I inserted it into a copier/printer at my local FedEx Office, I had to use their computer to print files from the drive.
I do not why It has 114GB when it must be 128GB
These flash drives are very easy to use. My only complaint is that I wish there was some color variation between their various flash drives with a larger storage capacity.
When I opened the drive it stated 232.8 GB capacity.

reviewTitle: These are FAT32 formats and not NTFS - 4 Gig transfer limit
reviewDescription: I didn't know these were FAT32 formats, which have a limit of 4 gig for file transfers.  This format dates back to Windows 95.  If you have a lot of small files to backup, no problem, but if you are trying to copying anything over 4 gig it will tell you "No enough space" even though you might have 45 gig free.

reviewTitle: Couldn't write to USB on Windows 11
reviewDescription: On Windows 11 I had no choice but to encrypt these USB disks with Bitlocker. After I did that I was unable to write anything to these disks because it said they were write protected. I am aware this may not be an issue with these USB drives but could be a Windows 11 issue, but I dug around and it seems like others have had issues with BitLocker. Just wanted to post as a heads up.

Failed after only 30 Days.

reviewDescription: I didn't like anything about it. What I dislike instead, it was not a 128 GB. It was only a hundred and fifteen. It's not a quality flash drive joke.

reviewTitle: Unable to use the secure feature
reviewDescription: I have always used SanDisk USB drives to backup my work because of the security features and always been very satisfied with their performance.  I purchased these drives with the same expectation, but I will be returning them.  On my previous drives, setting my password was very simple.  I selected the RunSanDiskSecure_Win.  On these drives that option is not available.  The only selection available is to Install SanDisk Software, which is a link to their website.  On that website the only option is to download the Private Access software.  But it will not download to my PC and I am unable to download it to the USB Drive.  This is a shame, but I will be looking into other options for a secure drive.
rediculously slow. Pure junk

Windows 10 cannot see this drive... and I worked through at least 10 solutions. I'm a retired tech, so I am familar with the utilities involved in making this work. It doesn't. Works fine with Linux, so I gave it to my husband. Will not buy Sandisk again, tho

It performs great as soon as I plug it into my computer it reads it super fast to move archives it looks really nice and stylish
Cheap plastic, but works as needed

Nothing new here, just the results of my initial tests.TL;DR:  Seems genuine, no bad sectors.  Only 460GB, not for people in a hurry.  Verify a SuperSpeed connection.lsusb -v shows:-------------------------------------------  idVendor  0x0781 SanDisk Corp.  idProduct  0x5581 Ultra  iProduct  2  SanDisk 3.2Gen1-------------------------------------------One USB 3 hub  detected this as HighSpeed and another SuperSpeed.  Not sure why, but USB 3 hubs always surprise me.The disk came FAT 32 formatted, with 3 useless files (I don;t do Windows or Mac):-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  707152 Sep 23  2021 'Install SanDisk Software.exe'-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  552605 Sep 23  2021 'Install SanDisk Software.dmg'-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root  300509 Sep 23  2021 'SanDisk Software.pdf'I use the Fight Flash Fraud (F3) software to verify my flash devices.  This one checked out well:-------------~ # f3probe /dev/sdcF3 probe 8.0Copyright (C) 2010 Digirati Internet LTDA.This is free software; see the source for copying conditions.[...]Good news: The device `/dev/sdc' is the real thingDevice geometry:  *Usable* size: 460.27 GB (965246976 blocks)  Announced size: 460.27 GB (965246976 blocks)  Module: 512.00 GB (2^39 Bytes)  Approximate cache size: 0.00 Byte (0 blocks), need-reset=no  Physical block size: 512.00 Byte (2^9 Bytes)Probe time: 2'57"-------------------------------------As others noted, this only has 460GB usable.  Deceptive marketing.I had not noticed the device was running as HighSpeed, but as others have noted, when writing USB 2 and 3 are about the same.  If took just over 9 hours to fill the thing!----------------------------------------~ # f3write /mnt/usb [ ...]Average writing speed: 14.08 MB/s---------------------------------------Reading it all back showed zero errors, but took almost 3 hours and 30 mins!---------------------------------------Average reading speed: 36.37 MB/s---------------------------------------So writing as SuperSpeed would not have gone faster.Moving it to a hub that detected this as SuperSpeed read it back in just under 53 min:---------------------------------------Average reading speed: 149.60 MB/s---------------------------------------The cheap thumbdrives keep calling me, and turn out to be junk.  This is the real deal.

reviewTitle: Reliable Drives, But Slow Write Speeds and No Activity Light
reviewDescription: I recently purchased a 3-pack of these SanDisk Ultra 32GB flash drives. They have a nice compact design that slides easily onto a keychain or in a pocket. The USB 3.0 interface means fast data transfer speeds when using USB 3.0 ports.However, I was disappointed to find the write speeds limited to USB 2.0 speeds, even when plugged into USB 3.0 ports. Saving large files seems to crawl compared to reads. There is also no LED activity light, so you don't know when data is transferring.That said, the read speeds are fast, allowing quick access to media and documents. The drives feel well-constructed and sturdy. And you can't beat getting 3 drives for the price.Overall, the drives work reliably and I'd purchase them again for the convenience of having multiple flash drives. But the slow write speeds and lack of activity indicator prevent this from being a 5 star product. I'm taking off 1 star for those shortcomings, so 4 stars from me.

Since my current vehicle doesn’t have a CD player or satellite radio, I wanted to use these to store and play music in the car. All of my CD collection has been converted to mp3 and is stored on a drive with other downloaded music to supply these USB drives for music playing.

I was pleased with the earlier versions of Cruzers from SanDisk I've used. But these 32 GB Ultra 3.0s are junk. I bought two 3-packs of them, and two of them--with only moderate use--have become mechanically unusable. The USB slide-out connector of one got out of line and was more and more difficult to insert in the slot--until finally it fell out. On the other, the solid bar on one side that ensures correct alignment into the slot moved from tight to the side to out in the middle of the end of the enclosure. After that it wouldn't seat into the slot at all. I had more than 20 Gb of essential data on that thing, and if I hadn't had a duplicate elsewhere the data loss would have been catastrophic. These things are poorly made junk. Avoid.

Why are USB flash drives so chintzy now? No LED on the drive, you don't know when it's reading/writing. This one has rounded slippery edges and it always slips out of my hand. The back of it has a flared edge that slips between my fingers. I literally drop it every time. Maybe these are trivial complaints, but they are annoying nonetheless.
Not working

Best to spend a bit extra and buy a quality one.  Hopefully the future versions are improved, but for now, it's long-term functionality is an "L" for me.

reviewDescription: Not sure what is occupying 52 gb of space in this 512 gb USB drive as only 460 gb free space is available,

reviewTitle: This does not have 512 gb of storage. It only has 460 gb of storage.
reviewDescription: So I do very much like the item. I needed a decent USB for usage in my schooling and this one does the job. The main issue I have with it though is that the one I received did not actually have 512 gb of storage. It only has 460 gb of storage. Which is a far cry from 512 gb of storage. I would have rated this item a 5/5 if the storage was actually 512 because this genuinely is a good item. But it is lacking 52 gbs of space so I think that this item shouldn't have been falsely advertised in this manner.

reviewTitle: Really crappy casing and button to open
reviewDescription: Drive is fine. The case it comes in is really crap. It is cheap thin plastic. The button that you push to advance or retract the USB connector is difficult to work because the plastic itself has no tension - so you can't "feel" the button pushing in to "release" and can't know when to push it to advance or retract the connector. Its pretty nerve wracking if you have important information on the drive - I never know if I am going to be able to open or close it, or if by trying, I will break the mechanism and won't be able to access my data. I would look for a different manufacturer next time.BTW - it didn't run hot for me.I bought two, and I wish I hadn't. Too nerve-wracking.

reviewTitle: Works Perfectly (But Fiddly To Plug In)
reviewDescription: It does exactly what it says it does, and what it should do. Its great. Except that, if you have fumble fingers (I have severe arthritis) it is difficult to hold in a way that doesn't push the plug into the body instead of actually plugging into the computer. It is entirely disability unfriendly, which is a shame because I never had this problem with past versions. If this had some kind of "lock" to keep the USB part of the device outside of the body, it would be perfect. This is not hard to design, lots of USB devices have them. I incorrectly assumed this one would have something similar, too. Great buy for someone who can use it, not so much for someone who has weak fingers. Otherwise it would get five stars.

This thing transfers data super slow. Even plugged into a USB 3.0 port it will slow down quickly and become ridiculously slow compared to other drives. My guess is it has something built in to limit itself to not overheat. Would not buy again.
Only came with 460MB available storage.

reviewTitle: Beware: no LED indicator for drive activity
reviewDescription: I have 20 or 30 SanDisk products, all of which have performed fine with regard to specs. As USB 3.0 flash drives, these do the job I bought them for: creating USB boot drives for installing system image backups. That's a long job for Windows 10 now that it needs 16GB of space instead of 8GB. I thought these drives would have some type of LED indicator of drive activity, but there's nothing at all to indicate whether the drive is still reading or writing data. Other USB drives I have (A-Data, Kingston, Transcend) all have drive activity LEDs. SanDisk can do better at this price point. Also the plastic around where a lanyard would be attached is too thin.
It may work just fine storing data but I bought it to use with my Blink camera system.  Blink said their system can use 256gb.  But this didn’t work with it.
The device works fine but the body of the device is super cheap and flimsy.

Meh. Capacity is what it is, they are never what they are billed to be. Dozens of GB short.Poor design flaw though for using on a keychain. It comes open from the key ring, other keys, and moving it around. What's worse is it closes with much more fuss- you need the button to close but not to open.So now this thing is open all the time, begging the question of why make it retractable if it cant stay tucked away?Not sure I would buy this again and would definitely not recommend for someone who plans on carrying it on their keys.Otherwise it performs basic cursory functions of a flash thumb drive.

Once upon a time 256Mb was considered pretty good for a thumb drive.  Now you get 256Gb for even less!  I used these to share converted home video with family members.
